displayed_text: Patient: Two months, two weeks, yeah. Doctor: Was at zero point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay, so that’s very good news because it’s a very slight - Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it was zero point three. The time before that it was like two months before and went from point three to point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay and I did mention to you that your testosterone is also going up. Patient: Right. Doctor: However, I think given the fact that you’re feeling relatively well. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Except for that slight increase in fatigue, perhaps, and given that the PSA level is still very low, and I can’t imagine that a PSA of zero point five comes high to you or your body or you know increase the risk of this prostate cancer causing you know either side effects or um you know even death because it’s still quite low. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh some data that said people who are on Enzalutamide stay on Enzalutamide and get these drugs uh may have a higher response rate, and that’s what we are testing. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have done this already in fifteen men and I think three people benefited for a period of time, relatively short. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But still benefited and so they did not have Enzalutamide or the Xtandi, so we’re doing fifteen more who have Xtandi uh and seeing whether or not it’s a higher response because of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So technically your ARV7 right now is positive enough to go on, your PSA is rising, you’re on the Xtandi, okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The worry is the lungs, okay because this is a treatment that if we turn on your immune system so loud it can attack your normal body. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So you can get a non-infectious pneumonia and get really short of breath and it fills up with scar tissue and s tuff like that and that we have to stop with steroids.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or commonly known as Lupron is the brand name. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s other brands too, but that’s the brand we use. Family Member: Okay. Okay. And anything else? I’m asking all the questions. (Laughs) Patient: No. I just…. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I’m gonna have J___ come in so. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Thank you. Doctor: Okay, we have a communication study. Healthcare Professional: He’s already part of us. This is a survey for you to fill out.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: - that he has. Family Member: Exactly. Doctor: That’s basically still there. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But because the PSA was doing a little bit of this creep up- Family Member: Creep up. Um hum. Doctor: We rechecked him. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then he’s got a couple of new spots in the bone which just happens to be in your skull. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Which is, you know, no different than it is in the leg and what not but it’s a signal to us.

Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else. Patient: We’ve got a lot of Christmas shopping to do. Family Member: I can do the Christmas shopping. Doctor: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing? Family Member: No, he ain’t gonna do that. Doctor: Oh my gosh! Family Member: But you know he’s bad about taking his pain pills, too. Family Member: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting? Doctor: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain. Family Member: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it? Doctor: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic. Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel –

Doctor: Sure. What we will- the nice part about this, is you sign up for what you can do. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. During the- this is different than the Lupron and that right? Isn’t this usually used for gastric? Doctor: It’s all, yeah, but there’s a lot of information for earlier states like now. So it’s also been given in men right before their surgery stages. We know that the cancer cells are dying in the actual prostate. So it’s been given in every possible place, but the FDA approval is when you’re castrate resistant. Yeah. Patient: Okay. That’s what I read. Doctor: I know. Man. What happened here? Did you teach him stuff? Family Member: I didn’t, actually. Doctor: Wow. That’s great. Family Member: He’s a smart guy. Doctor: He is a smart guy. (Laughs) Patient: I used to do research for college professors sometimes in school. Patient: I used to work in the library, and they’d come in, can you give me a bibliography of the? (Laughs) Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ours isn’t back yet, but his is going up. Patient: Yeah I mean I… Doctor: Mhmm Patient: I think I started chemo and I was in the low thirties. I went down in to twenties and I’m back up to thirty I think the last one from B______. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. You know the lymph nodes are starting to grow again. Just plumpier um Patient: I had a CT scan Doctor: Yeah Patient: this morning and we asked for a stat read, but it… Doctor: Yeah. That’s the one. Patient: Okay. Wow. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m reading Patient: That’s- They were really quick. Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And you know I’m always happy to consider stuff experimental- Patient: Right. Doctor: -but at this moment we don’t have one that is exactly like this. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right. And this is ready to go FDA, four pills a day, Patient: Okay. Doctor: that’s it. Just one time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um and it’s proven to help improve for you to live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: For folks just like you. Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them? Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And so those are all issues that you’ve got to sort out. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: How do you know it’s working? Family Member: I think that we should probably wait until catheter is out.

Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost? Patient: Probably a program. Doctor: ‘Cuz we would put the prescription into our pharmacy. We would have them figure out how much it’s gonna cost you, and then if it’s too much, they could start looking for these plans that they cover the cost for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if that’s so, then it would be cheap. Then you would be taking a drug that I don’t think is gonna work with the idea that I need you to be on this drug so that the immune therapy might work which is research, experimental, unsure. Okay? Family Member: Is there any way on the portal – his daughter wants to keep up what’s, what’s going over -- like what we said today. Does she have your power of something? Have some way that she can check on, uh – like MyLGHHealth, I can go in there and see, read everything, and results and that. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, he is active on MyChart. That’s where I wrote you that note.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they have to show that either your nerves are not working, your, uh, legs are not working, something or the other before we Patient: I wonder why they ain’t working good. Doctor: Yeah. So, they will say, “Did you try a walker? Did you try a this or that?” Patient: I, I, uh got a cane. I had a walker. Doctor: Okay. Now, Patient: Then I got a, then I got Doctor: Then, you got to try it. I don’t see you using it. Patient: I got it down ‘cuz it don’t, it don’t really be working for me. You know what I’m sayin’? ‘Cuz all I do is when I stop, I lean on it, lean down on it. I’d settle for the one with the seat on it. Now see, that’s the one that, um, I gotta see, if, if you can, can you see when the next time I can get one? The one with the seat on it? Doctor: The walker with the seat? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’ll give you script for that to take…

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The bone biopsy for you would be similar to any kind of biopsy. They have to numb up your skin, and put a needle, and take a piece of whatever they’re trying to take a piece of. For us, the bone biopsy, the yield is much lower, meaning they don’t always get actual tumor cells, because within the bone, it’s just they’re sort of taking a shot at, you know, what they think might be the tumor. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but those trials are, are, uh, the primary hormone in this case it would be drug called, Xtandi, plus another pill. So it’s a pill-based kind of trial in that sense. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the, uh, the other trial we have is my, I talked before about this bone marrow transplant trial, which, um, is, you know, more kind of aggressive, uh, and kind of still in its early stages. So I can’t tell ya much about- we’ve treated two patients, and, uh, they both did really well with the bone marrow transplant. One guy has been pretty stable for, you know, going on two years, and one guy’s disease responded, and then it sort of progressed now, and he’s, he’s on chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So probably one guy benefited and one guy has not. Uh, we’re about to do a third guy probably in the next few weeks. So, uh, but I think that trial I would probably want you to have at least been on one of the hormone drugs first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because those drugs do improve how long people live and are relatively easy. So I think I would, even though that’s my trial, the bone marrow transplant trial, it’s designed for people like you who are young- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Um, the, uh, I would rather first do something that at least has a track record of success. Does that make sense?

Patient: Yeah, it’s all – it’s all good. Doctor: That’s all okay? Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: That has not acted up or gotten worse in the last few… Patient: No, no. Not since I went back on the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve been fine since then. Doctor: And you’re still on the low dose right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Now your doctor wanted to get you off the prednisone and try Cymbalta? Patient: Well he mentioned, well he was asking me about stuff and I was telling him about the you know the blah, blah, blah. Doctor: Yeah that you’re on. Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta.

Patient: Can I do anything. I mean… Doctor: Yeah I mean I think if we don’t get an answer today we’re gonna have to shoot somebody there. Doctor: That’s on video too. Yeah. Patient: We got this. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: Is there anything… Doctor: Well the good news is – no – I mean the good news is you know whether you get it today or next week, it doesn’t matter. You’ll still do well. Patient: But, okay, okay. Doctor: You’ll still do… Patient: That’s my only concern because because whoever called to schedule it said R__ you can do it before the holiday or do it afterward. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: We’ve got family coming and stuff like that too so… Doctor: So I think you should just do it after you know you finish radiation June eighth so that’s we’re covered and everything is great, your counts are fine. So you know you’re anemic is still at, your hemoglobin is still at eight point nine.

Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that. Doctor: So -. Family Member: Does insurance do anything with this? I mean, do they consider you a risk? Are you -- Doctor: I don’t know. Um, you, you, they’re going to need to talk with their doctors. I do know that the test we did, I think, allows, if we, a discounted test, I’ll find out --- for family members, um, to test as well. Um, there is just a test for BRCA, and then there’s a, you know, at this point these tests are, cover about thirty different genes. Um. That’s the only one they found. So, for your family, I think it, it requires a discussion about it, and then they should – you know, they need to make a decision if they want to get tested or not. Um. It’s a risk factor for prostate and breast. So, and ovarian, so both sons and daughters, and then, you know, their sons and daughters if they – I would say if they were positive. If they were negative, there’s – you know, your grandkids are – it, it can’t skip over it – so, if your sons or daughter is negative (coughs) Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Unless their – Family Member: Their husband has it – Doctor: Unless their husband or wife has it. Family Member: Right. Well the one that has, um, the children, is in the military. So, she has access to really good medical care and probably could do this at little cost or, I don’t know. Patient: Well. Who cares about the cost for Christ’s sake? Family Member: Well, no, I mean, but she has good medical care. So. Doctor: Well, again, I could, we could even do the test we just did, um, Family Member: It’s easy for her to get tested for anything. You know what I mean? If she wants to.
